Has anyone else noticed that quite a few of the associate level questions say something like "as a team lead"? I find it more pretty annoying, admittedly more annoying than it should be.

Are the people earning developer associate certs really team leads?

stories.text:
Setting aside recent hipster posts about logging being dead...

I continually run into the issue when making CLI apps: where does logging go?

stdout is terrible, logging would pollute information you want piped to other programs and is noise

stderr isn't great, because log messages are more status than errors, and usually breaks error detection, handling, and processing.

Most logging frameworks I've seen belch to stdout or stderr by default. Yuck.

Most alternatives (enabled by logging frameworks) is a logfile is ... ok, but then you have logfiles polluting your FS in arbitrary locations, and the logfile location and name is going to be highly unstandardized.

So why isn't there a standard notion of stdlog in UNIXland alongside stdin, stdout, and stderr?
stories.title: Unix: Why Not Stdlog?

stories.text:
Just a heads up so others can avoid similar: Heroku gives 7 days' notice before deleting databases on their Hobby Basic tier once it exceeds >10GB or >10m rows. [1]

Hobby Basic tier is meant for "Small side projects and proof-of-concepts" [2]. It's possible for a startup to spend a lot of time in this tier because it spans from tiny (10k rows, to quite large 10m rows). Many startups reach $m valuations with smaller databases.

What happened to:

> Anything that can go wrong will go wrong.

If your db admin's takes a week's holidays, they could return and find the database missing.

An unexpected grown surge could push your db past its limits earlier than anticipated and an alert email could easily be missed.

Heroku's own infrastructure could go down at an inopportune time, preventing maintenance. For example heroku's database metrics page is currently not displaying database metrics for some databases - including for this one with 7 days to live. What should be displayed [3], what is actually displayed [4].

Even in perfect circumstances, 7 days is just too aggressive.

[1] https://i.imgur.com/FDF6Gu4.png

[2] https://www.heroku.com/pricing#data-services

[3] https://i.imgur.com/tAmmNx5.png

[4] https://i.imgur.com/DUdXB7P.png
stories.title: Heroku Will Delete 8m Row Database with 7 Days' Notice
